properties.Name: JournalTransaction
properties.Description:
A Transaction records the economic events of the enterprise recorded by accountants to accounts.

Transactions are activities that affect what a business owns, what a business owes and the ownership of the business.   

Transactions are recorded in account(s).     The purpose of the account is to record the information about each business transaction.     

Each part of the transaction will have an effect on a specific ledger account.

Each business transaction involves changes to at least two accounts in a double entry account system.  For any transaction, debits must equal credits.

Each transaction causes at least two changes on the balance sheet.
Transactions must be reported consistently in the same way from period to period.

There are two parties involved in each transaction:   The legal entity recording the transaction (RECORD-KEEPING LEGAL ENTITY) and the other party involved (PARTY).     The other party can also be a legal entity so "Reporting Legal Entity" makes it clear that is the business keeping the books.

Each transaction is first entered into a journal or 'day book' and then posted to a ledger.

Note:
Not all events are transactions.  For example, a change in value of an asset such as land is an example.

Banking Example:
When you deposit a check the bank credits your checking account and debits their cash position.

Note:  Related Transactions are handled by the source document rather than an explicit RELATED TRANSACTION entity.   If the customer feels that this isn't sufficient then a RELATED TRANSACTION entity can be added.

Columns.Name: TransactionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction.

Columns.Name: JournalTransactionTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction Type.

Columns.Name: RecordKeepingLegalEntityId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the book-keeping or reporting Legal Entity.

Columns.Name: TransactionCounterPartyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Party.

Columns.Name: IntercompanyTransactionIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the transaction is between affiliated companies

Columns.Name: SourceDocumentId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a source document involved in a transaction.

Columns.Name: ExtraordinaryTransactionIndicator
Columns.Description:
A transaction that meets two conditions: 

(1) unusual in nature

(2) infrequent in occurrence

Columns.Name: AccountingProcedureTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Accounting Procedure Type.

Columns.Name: ResponsibilityCenterId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Responsibility Center.

Columns.Name: ProjectId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Project.

Columns.Name: WorkOrderId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Work Order.

Columns.Name: CustomerAccountId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer Account.

Each transaction is first entered into a journal or 'day book' and then posted to a ledger.
